bestBHT.bht: The faith that the Thessalonians demonstrated became a means of applying consolation to Paul's mind, providing him with comfort even in the midst of his distress and affliction. Their endurance amidst external trials uplifted and encouraged Paul, showing him that his labor had not been in vain. Their faithfulness served as a source of light, cheering the heart of the apostle and enabling him to endure his own troubles with greater equanimity. The news of their good condition brought him immense relief and comfort, serving as a fresh stimulus to his own patience.

Henry Alford: You were the object of our consolation: the faith which you showed was the means whereby that object was applied to our minds."
In spite of all our distress and affliction."
We may well imagine such external trouble.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: In the midst of... notwithstanding 'all our distress and affliction,'
External trials at Corinth, whence Paul writes.
Albert Barnes: Their steadfastness was a great source of comfort to him in his trials.
It was an instance where the holy lives and the fidelity of a people did much, as will always be the case, to lighten the burdens and cheer the heart of a minister of the gospel.
In the inevitable trials of the ministerial office there is no source of comfort more rich and pure than this.
Marvin Vincent: The derivation from agxein to press tightly, to choke (Lightfoot, Ellicott) is doubtful.
In the sense of urgency, distress, seldom in Class.
Philip Schaff: The tidings which Paul received of the stedfastness of his Thessalonians under trial, enabled him to endure his own troubles with greater equanimity.
Their continued faith showed him that his former labours and trials had not been in vain.
Their affection and sympathy cheered him, and their uncomplaining endurance was a fresh stimulus to his own patience.
Archibald T. Robertson: Over you (εφ' υμιν). Επ with the locative, the basis on which the 'comfort' rests."
Distress (αναγκη). Physical necessity, common sense in late Greek, choking (αγχω, ανγορ), and crushing trouble (θλιψισ, θλιβω).
John Gill: This gave abundant consolation in all our affliction and distress.
The news of the good estate and condition the Thessalonians were in, was a great relief and comfort to him.

bhtAttempts.bht: The Thessalonians' unwavering faith brought great consolation to Paul amidst his own distress and affliction. Despite the external trials and difficulties he faced, their steadfastness gave him comfort and encouragement. Their holy lives and faithfulness served as a source of light and encouragement for Paul as he carried out his ministry. The news of their continued faith showed him that his efforts had not been in vain and buoyed his spirits. Their affection and endurance served as a fresh stimulus to his own patience, and their good condition brought him immense relief and comfort.

The Thessalonians' unwavering faith brought great consolation to Paul amidst his own distress and affliction. Their steadfastness served as a source of light and encouragement, showing him that his efforts had not been in vain. Their affection and endurance stimulated his patience, and the news of their good condition was a great relief to him. By sharing their faith, the Thessalonians provided comfort in the midst of external trials, offering support and solace to Paul in his time of need.

The Thessalonians' unwavering faith brought great consolation to Paul amidst his own distress and affliction. Their steadfastness served as a source of light and encouragement, showing him that his efforts had not been in vain. Their affection and endurance stimulated his patience, and the news of their good condition was a great relief to him. By sharing their faith, the Thessalonians provided comfort in the midst of external trials and supported Paul in his time of need.

The faith that the Thessalonians demonstrated became a means of applying consolation to Paul's mind, providing him with comfort even in the midst of his distress and affliction. Their endurance amidst external trials uplifted and encouraged Paul, showing him that his labor had not been in vain. Their faithfulness served as a source of light, cheering the heart of the apostle and enabling him to endure his own troubles with greater equanimity. The news of their good condition brought him immense relief and comfort, serving as a fresh stimulus to his own patience.

The Thessalonians' faith was a source of consolation to Paul amidst his distress and affliction. Their endurance amidst trials uplifted him, showing that his labor was not in vain. Their faithfulness provided light and encouragement, enabling him to endure his own troubles. The news of their good condition brought him relief, stimulating his patience. Their unwavering faith applied comfort to Paul's mind, providing solace in the face of external trials.
